awd_titl_txt: LEAPS-MPS: Structural and Functional Characterization of Tick Vaccine Antigen Homologs
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).  In this project, funded by the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate and housed in the Chemistry Division, Professor Erica Jacobs and her students at Saint John’s University will study the relationship between the structure of a chemical (Bm86, a recombinant protein) found in a bovine anti-tick vaccine and its function.  These studies are expected to provide insight into how Bm86 provides immunity from ticks. Prof. Jacobs’s broadening participation plan includes paying undergraduate and MS students (at Saint John’s University, a minority serving institution) to support their research experiences in place of external jobs, and development of course-based undergraduate research (CURE) experiences that will introduce a much broader audience to research experiences than would otherwise be possible.  She will also increase her ongoing efforts to incorporate antiracist pedagogy into Chemistry courses.

Professor Jacobs proposes to examine structural parameters of the recombinant protein Bm86, which is an anti-tick vaccine antigen, and its homologs, with the hypothesis that particular structural features of Bm86 and its homologs in the tick Ixodes scapularis underlie the effectiveness of immune responses directed against them.  She will also examine functional parameters of Bm86 homologs by defining their protein interactomes in tick cell homogenates and bovine blood via an affinity purification approach, with the hypothesis that Bm86 homologs bind to cellular or extracellular matrix receptors in the tick gut, leading to cell signaling and/or adhesion events.  It is further hypothesized that these proteins, which are expressed in the lumen of the tick gut, may have additional binding partners in bovine blood, identification of which may lead to insight as to function of these proteins.  Proposed work is highly collaborative and will provide research experiences to undergraduate and MS students from groups traditionally underrepresented in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

This project advanced fundamental knowledge of tick parasitology and methods in bioanalytical chemistry and structural biology. We used an integrative approach to determine the previously unknown 3-dimensional shape of a particular tick gut protein, Bm86, that has previously been utilized as a vaccine target to protect livestock from ticks and the diseases they transmit. The strategy involved gathering a diverse set of experimental enzymatic, chemical cross-linking, and mass spectrometric data. The resulting data were translated into spatial restraints and used to map protein structures via integrative modeling. Using this approach, we produced the first structures of Bm86 proteins from several tick species. We developed new integrative modeling techniques that other researchers will be able to apply to their proteins of interest.

Our results show that the protein from the tick species that transmits Lyme disease in the Northeastern US, Ixodes scapularis, has considerably more sugar modifications than similar proteins from cattle ticks. These sugar modifications may shield the protein from the antibodies produced by vaccines, thereby lowering vaccine immunogenicity and efficacy. In summary, the project resulted in a better understanding of key differences between tick species that transmit disease, and a more complete toolkit of techniques to study other protein structures.

Broader impacts

Results from this project were presented at two international meetings and disseminated to the broader scientific community. The project resulted in the support and training of six undergraduates at a minority-serving, primarily undergraduate institution. These students were trained in cutting-edge techniques in the career-relevant fields of mass spectrometry/proteomics.  In addition, the grant supported development of two new lab courses that broadened participation in STEM research at a larger scale than a normal undergraduate research group (12-16 per lab section). One lab, a course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE), was described and published as a free resource for other educators to replicate or modify. (https://serc.carleton.edu/curenet/collection.html?search_text=Jacobs&Search=search). Finally, as the details of the link between vaccine immunogenicity/efficacy and 3-dimensional structure is elucidated, this work is expected to contribute to the process of understanding how to make more effective vaccines.


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Erica Y Jacobs
